model.hed: Best Resorts and Safari Camps in Africa: Readers' Choice Awards
model.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate the top resorts and safari camps in South Africa, Botswana, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Kenya, and Rwanda

memberComments.comment: "One of my best travel experiences ever. Service is over the top, food is amazing and varied, and all staff is extremely friendly. The game drives were wonderful, and they have added surprises at every corner. They treat you like royalty. Forest rooms were spotless. Can't wait to try another &Beyond property. They are true luxury."
"Luxurious hotel in the game reserve. The service was very good and staff very friendly."
Spectacular game viewing, wonderful rooms They do try a little TOO hard to make sure everyone sees everything so the pace seems to be rushed.
"Located in the heart of the Masai Mara, maybe best wildlife area in Kenya. Offers tent rooms that give you the feel of where you are. Excellent dining and bar facilities."
"Safari is a must and I would stay here again and again."
Great location, excellent service, food and accommodations. Close access to game drives, beautiful scenery and local Masai Mara villages.
Excellent game lodge! Beautiful view and the room was wonderful, food terrific, staff five star service. Enjoyed our stay and would go back.

Fabulous place, great safari. Its famous for its huge herds of elephant and over 450 bird species.  Food is good, Almost always buffet style. Also best place to view animals along the riverbanks - Lodges are wonderful and people are very friendly. Felt safe and had a great time.

This, to us, is the best of the best in Victoria Falls. It is a five minute shuttle ride from Victoria Falls (service provided free from the Safari Lodge) and in return we got to watch animals at the water hole and see warthogs trimming the lawn.
What a great way to experience the African bush. Great location, good food and friendly staff.
Wonderful view of the Serengeti from our room in a rondavel. Excellent food and service.
Great place to unwind after a safari.
Amazing service and people, wonderful location, fabulous tree house. Romantic & remote with elephants walking through camp.

items.name: Masai Mara Sopa Lodge, Maasai Mara
Victoria Falls Safari Lodge
items.description: Opened in 1994, this property a couple of miles from the Victoria Falls Rain Forest is like a multi-level, open-plan tree house. The focal point of the hotel—which is surrounded by lilies, Zimbabwe creepers, and acacia, mopani, teak, and baobab trees—is a water hole that attracts kudu, impalas, elephants, and white-backed vultures year-round. "The wildlife are a sight to behold." All rooms are done in bright-colored local fabrics and have private balconies overlooking the unfenced Zambezi National Park. MaKuwa-Kuwa restaurant faces a water hole, while The Boma serves local and international fare accompanied by traditional dancing and drumming.

items.name: Serengeti Sopa Lodge
items.description: A modern lodge on the edge of the Serengeti, rooftop views from here are spectacular. 69 rooms and 4 suites are decorated in bright, cheerful colors. Although not a safari lodge, balloon rides and bird watching expeditions can be arranged through the resort.

fields.caption:
**Rooms:** 100


**Service:** 100


**Food: **91.3


**Location: **95.8


**Design: **100


**Activities: **95.8







This camp is on rehabilitated land formerly used to grow pineapple, cotton, and sisal, near the Ubombo Mountains. Guests experience "all the comforts, but get them in the wilderness," where zebras, impalas, and wildebeests roam. Six different lodges, ranging in design from avant-garde to pueblo-influenced, are set on a cliff face, in a dry sand forest, or by an extinct volcano. Some have high-gloss wood floors, rich fabrics, and crimson Zulu artifacts. "Zulu trackers are as friendly and knowledgeable as they come," and the perfect-scoring resort staff are "an absolute joy."

items.name: Camp Okavango
items.description: The thatched main lodge shaded by mangosteen trees sits amid floodplains and savannahs. "Very comfortable safari-style tents" on teak platforms have sliding doors leading to decks. "Outstanding staff make many different activities possible," including a boat trip to "an island visited by elephants." Meals depend on seasonal ingredients and include dishes like kudu steak.

items.name: Mombo Camp and Little Mombo
items.description: Expect to see lions, leopards, zebras, and more on the game drives of this two-part camp near bush, plains, and wetlands. Comfort is the norm inside the tents, which are elevated into the tree canopy and have wood beams, outdoor showers, and private verandas. Meals exceed expectations and are served anywhere on the property.

items.name: Fairmont Mara Safari Club
items.description: Guests spot gazelles and lions from the tents along the banks of the Mara River—"an unforgettable safari experience." Accommodations have Masai colors on the bedspreads and beaded curtains from South Africa in the bathroom area. Tents were recently renovated and changed from green to beige, which keeps them cooler in hot weather. Meals at the boma, designed to resemble a Masai manyatta, or village, are served indoors and out and focus on barbecue—spit-roasted goat, rosemary-scented chicken, and river crocodile skewers. Cool off in the kidney-shaped pool.

items.name: Governors' Camps
items.description: This camp, formerly reserved for Kenya's colonial governors, offers accommodations that include East African-style safari tents with private verandas and Masai interiors with flashes of suede and leather. Spot elephants, hippos, and buffalo on game drives with attentive staff during the day and enjoy candlelit three-course dinners in the evening.

items.name: Fairmont Mount Kenya Safari Club
items.description: Opened by actor William Holden in 1959 at the base of Mount Kenya, this equatorial property has over 100 acres of lawns, streams, and gardens. Rooms have hardwood floors, verandas, and fireplaces, and the hotel’s two restaurants have views of Mount Kenya.

fields.credit: Courtesy Fairmont Mount Kenya Safari Club

items.name: Amboseli Serena Safari Lodge
items.description: This property, set beneath giant acacia trees and beside a natural spring, lies in the shadow of Kilimanjaro. "Watching hundreds of monkeys walking single file to the river to get a drink in the morning was the highlight of my vacation." Inspired by local Masai primary colors and shapes, "attractive and comfortable rooms" are furnished with African murals painted by a local artist. "The staff knew us on a first-name basis and vice versa. It was the best service and friendliest atmosphere I've ever encountered at a hotel." All meals are served at the main restaurant; "plentiful buffets include local specialties, but the food is just okay." The "unbeatable location" provides the opportunity to see elephants, lions, baboons, and more than 450 species of birds.

items.name: Sabyinyo Silverback Lodge
items.description: In the decade-plus since Rwanda’s devastating 1994 genocide, tourism has been gradually rebounding, and emerging ventures that complement the country’s natural riches, including the much-anticipated Sabyinyo Silverback Lodge, are now opening their doors. From the deep veranda of any of the eight chalets (outfitted in warm hues and African materials), you can see the mist-shrouded hills made famous by the late zoologist Dian Fossey. On one side are the slopes of Sabyinyo, one of five inactive volcanoes in the park, making this the first high-end lodging in an area that, along with the adjoining parks in Uganda and Congo, is the last refuge of the endangered mountain gorilla. The property, owned by a community trust and run by Governors’ Camp in Kenya, is a special hybrid of safari lodge and small hotel—with the best elements of both (good taste, deluxe bathrooms, attentive staff). In the ranch-style main building, with its sweeping views, there’s a dining room with a menu that aims for haute (but falls short) and two large sitting areas with plush sofas. Fireplaces in both public and private spaces are for those cold, mosquito-less evenings that follow a muddy day in the park, wandering behind your guide to see one of the gorilla troops. The walk of a few hours costs about $500, but gorilla sightings are guaranteed and the rare experience is worth every Rwandan franc.

items.name: Bushmans Kloof Wilderness Reserve & Wellness Retreat
items.description: Located on 18,500-acres, this reserve offers light-filled contemporary rooms, a heated pool, a fitness center, and a spa. Meals at Makana draw from native fynbos herbs and local meat, and guests’ stays are elevated by the spirit and insight of an affable staff who happily share native culture and history.

items.name: Lion Sands
items.description: Set on the banks of the Sabi River, this luxurious resort on 10,000 acres comprises four lodges and a family camp. Ivory Lodge rooms, done in ebony and ivory, have African artifacts and views of the river from private terraces, while the cream and beige rooms at River Lodge have freestanding tubs as well as indoor and outdoor showers. After viewing elephants and lions on open jeep drives, enjoy traditional boma dining.

items.name: Londolozi Private Game Reserve and Camps
items.description: This five-camp preserve in a riverine forest offers "the vacation of a lifetime—everything is fabulous." In a perfect-scoring location on the Sand River, accommodations include Pioneer Camp, with three private suites decorated in Ralph Lauren style, and Varty Camp, where chalets in earth tones have private pools. Enjoy freshly baked muffins on the deck at sunrise while watching the elephants below—"an absolutely incredible experience." Dinners at the boma are served by candlelight on white linen. "The safaris are beyond fantastic. The Big Five are literally within reach!"

items.name: MalaMala Game Reserve
items.description: Opened in 1962, the reserve has three camps on the banks of the Sand River, with rondavel-style abodes and airy buildings that have white-paneled ceilings. Guests can view the Big Five, serval cats, side-striped jackals, and different species of mongoose. Meals are served on decks overlooking the river or in a reed-enclosed boma and include coq au vin and venison steak.

items.name: Sabi Sabi Private Game Reserve
items.description: You’ll spot giraffes, wildebeests, and lions during three-hour game drives at this remote game reserve with four luxury lodges. Selati Camp has a colonial feel, while Earth Lodge's furniture is made from uprooted trees. Dinners tend to be African barbecue dishes, but alternatives such as arugula with pine nuts and roasted peppers are also on offer.

fields.title: sabi-sabi-private-game-reserve-kruger-national-park-south-africa-amber-presidential-suite.jpg
fields.credit: Courtesy Sabi Sabi Private Game Reserve

items.name: Singita Kruger National Park
items.description: The two remote lodges—Lebombo and Sweni—are in a 33,000-acre concession and offer accommodations with two distinct looks: Lebombo has 15 loft-style glass, wood, and steel suites above the N'wanetsi River, while Sweni has six suites with an earthy palette, latte roofs, and outdoor showers overlooking the Sweni River. Safari guides bring guests close to lions, elephants, buffalo, zebras, and black rhinos.

items.name: Singita Sabi Sand
items.description: Adjacent to Kruger National Park, this three-lodge camp is surrounded by groves of acacia thornveld and marula trees on the Sand River. The contemporary Boulders Lodge has earth tones, glass walls, and private pool decks, while Castleton Lodge is an exclusive private rental with six cottages, pool, tennis court, spa, and gym. Guided safari walks are available upon request.

items.name: Kirawira Serena Camp
items.description: Located between the crocodile-rich Mbalageti and Grumeti rivers, this Edwardian-style camp on a hillside puts guests in log-tethered stone-and-thatch accommodations with steamer-trunk wardrobes and brass lamps. In addition to game drives, activities include guided nature hikes, crocodile safaris, and excursions to Lake Victoria.

items.name: Lake Manyara Tree Lodge, Tanzania
items.description: Set in a forest of mahogany trees, these spacious stilted treehouses are "romantic and remote, with elephants walking around them." Accommodations have contemporary furnishings and are decorated in warm tones. One past guest was thankful for the indoor bathtub, as "the outdoor shower we were looking forward to using was infested with bees." An open kitchen allows guests to see their pan-African meals being prepared; "amazing service" means breakfast on a table by the flamingo-ringed lakeshore. Giraffes and cheetahs roam the woodlands and lakeshore.

items.name: Singita Grumeti Reserves
items.description: Singita Grumeti is comprised of four permanent properties and one mobile camp – Singita Sasakwa Lodge, Singita Sabora Tented Camp, Singita Faru Faru Lodge, Singita Serengeti House and Singita Explore – all set within 350,000 acres of land adjoining Serengeti National Park.  Sasakwa Lodge, the most sumptuous, comprises nine cottages suites and one villa styled as colonial manor houses, with fireplaces, antique bath tubs, a wraparound veranda, a plunge pool, and Wi-Fi. Between game drives, guests can smoke complimentary cigars at the main lodge’s bar, take tea in the garden sunroom, shoot billiards on a nineteenth-century table, and make free satellite phone calls; other diversions include an archery range and a stable of horses for gallops alongside the herds. On an open plain, Sabora has nine tents furnished with antiques from an English lord’s East African campaign in a 1920s style. Faru Faru’s eight tents sit in wooded country by the Grumeti River. A return to the very essence of safari, Singita Explore is a private camp that moves according to where the best game viewing is within the Grumeti Reserves and provides access to the most remote and beautiful locations. Singita Serengeti House, is an exclusive-use retreat designed to welcome friends and families to a relaxed home away from home. Up to eight guests can stay at Serengeti House and they can choose between the two suites in the main house or the two garden suites situated on either side.

items.name: Serengeti Serena Safari Lodge
items.description: Perched on a ridge with views over the savanna, this lodge exudes traditional African architecture with grass-thatch huts that resemble the rondavel dwellings of a Masai village. Accommodations are charming with natural stone bathrooms and private balconies. Located in Serengeti National Park, guests can see the annual wildebeest migration or the Big Five.
